prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We ask for a spectral resolution of ~0.2 km/s for N2H+ (1-0) and 0.4 km/s for HNC (1-0) lines. This spectral resolution is enough to resolve the multiple velocity components along the line of sight (see Beuther et al. 2013, Peretto et al. 2013, ALMA data, also Fig.2 in this proposal), as well as to trace the infall motion with HNC (1-0) (e.g. Kirk et al. 2013). We ask for a spectral resolution of CH3OH (11-10) of ~0.8 km/s. This is enough to identify outflows in these regions (e.g. Zhang et al. 2015).
We set-up the last bandpass with the largest allowed window, 1875 MHz, and a coarse spectral resolution of 5.6 km/s. This configuration will allow the identification of astrochemical interesting lines and at the same guarantees a total bandwidth of ~2.7 GHz. This large bandwidth is required to reach the desired continuum sensitivity of ~40 uJy.
This configuration allows us to trace gas kinematics with enough resolution to achieve all our scientific goals, preserving enough spectral window for continuum emission without exceeding the data rate policy value.

We asked for a spatial resolution of 2.0". This is equivalent to a scale of ~0.05 pc at the average distance of 5 kpc. This is enough to resolve the fragments that we expect to see, of the size of cores, ~0.1 pc (Bergin & Tafalla 2007).
We ask to imaging each clump in a box of 55", ~1.4 pc at d~5kpc, enough to cover the whole clump.
We underline that we can combine ALMA data with our on-the-fly map taken at IRAM 30m, which cover a 2'x2' region across each clump, to recover the extended emission for both N2H+ (1-0) and HNC (1-0) data. Therefore, we do not need ACA complementary data. Also, from our IRAM 30m data we do not see structures more extended than ~30", which is only slightly more extended than the largest angular scale that we can recover without using the ACA. The main goal of this proposal is to study the kinematics in the embedded cores. At a distance of ~5kpc an angular scale of 25" corresponds to ~0.6 pc. This is 6 times larger than the size of the cores, and 3 times larger than the scale of the biggest fragment observed in Zhang et al. 2015 in their ALMA observations of a massive clumps at d~4.8 kpc.

We ask for a sensitivity of 8 mJy per channel. Our N2H+ (1-0) emission lines observed with IRAM 30m (an example is in Fig. 2, right) are similar to the same line observations done by Beuther et al. 2013 with Nobeyama 45m when scaled to the same resolution (peak emission ~1 Jy, eee also Fig 2, left). The weakest components resolved with PdBI in Beuther et al. 2013 using a resolution of ~3.5" and spectral resolution of 0.2 km/s, peak ~0.5 Jy (see Fig. 2). We asked for a spatial resolution of 2.0" and similar spectral resolution for N2H+ (1-0), our primary target, of ~0.2 km/s. We expect to observe line peaks not weaker than 100 mJy. Similar values are discussed in the N2H+ (1-0) data observed with ALMA by Peretto et al. 2013. Our sensitivity is enough to detect the weakest lines with ~10 sigma of confidence. The HNC (1-0) emission observed with IRAM 30m is similar or brighter than the N2H+ (1-0) in these regions. The CH3OH (11-10) emission, if present, is expected to be of the order of 50 mJy (Peretto et al. 2013, ALMA data) at our desired resolution.
The required configuration is also optimized to achieve a continuum sensitivity of ~40 uJy. This is enough to resolve fragments down to ~0.5 solar masses at an average distance of ~5 kpc (assuming spectral index beta=2 and a temperature value of 10 K), four times the thermal Jeans mass of the smallest fragments that we could observe if non-thermal motion is completely dumped down (~2 solar masses at an average distance of d~5 kpc). Also, extrapolating the flux at 3mm from our Hi-GAL data and assuming that half of the flux arises from the main core we will have a 25 sigma detection of the main fragment (~1 mJy).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Star forming regions are dominated by non-thermal, turbulent motion. In low-mass stars turbulence decays in the higher density regions with a transition to coherence in the densest, star forming, gas. In the handful of high-mass star forming regions investigated so far the role of turbulence is much less clear. There is evidence of turbulence dissipation from the scale of clumps (~1 pc) down to the small cores (~0.1 pc) in some regions, but a few turbulence dominated massive cores have also been identified. We have mapped a unique sample of massive starless clumps with the IRAM 30m telescope to trace the large scale dynamics of the gas. Remarkably the turbulence seems to increase in the denser regions of these clumps. However these objects can be clumpy and the observed trend could possibly be due to the blending of multiple velocity components along the line of sight. We propose to observe with ALMA a selected sample of 10 of these clumps aiming to investigate the role of the turbulence by studying the gas kinematics of the embedded cores. These observations will provide the first uniform study of the evolution of turbulence in a significant sample of well selected massive clumps.
